posts.name: ed
posts.cooked: Have you considered making a PR to the server repo? I’m interested in starting to contribute to the project, and am more interested in the server side of things as that is closer to my day job type work. Still figuring out how to get started. I think this would be helpful to myself and others.

posts.name: Arun Rao
posts.cooked:
Good work!

Have you considered containerizing it ? (Docker or Vagrant etc.)

posts.name: Johanw666
posts.cooked: Another section that might be usefull for people who want to run their own server is which changes to make to the client (URL, key’s).

I’ve made a lot of docker containers, even complex ones like a full Domain Controller running Samba4 with OpenVPN for multi-site (Docker). I would very much like to create a Docker version of the Signal Server. However, I am totally new to Signal’s infrastructure, so I’m looking at the above guide and have a number of questions. For instance, are S3 and Twilio required? As Johan mentions, what is required to change on the clients?

In an ideal world I’d like to set up a container that could be deployed anywhere, such as AWS, Linode, etc, without the need for any other services, and a second container that contains a set of scripts that pull down all the clients and compile them. Basically, a turn-key roll-your-own Signal.

If anyone is willing to help out, I’m happy to take the lead.
Ed, if you’re willing to help out on the server side, I could dockerize it and handle setting up scripts to compile clients.

Hey all, to not bombard @aqnouch’s deocumentation thread, I’ve created a separate one focused on a fork of Signal that supports URL selection for custom servers. Hope some of you are interested in participating!

Signal Fork: Self-hosted Signal - Interested? Server Development
Hi all, As I’ve been thinking about this a while, @aqnouch’s excellent first pass at documenting server setup (Signal Server Installation Guide) along with @ed2048’s desire to contribute on the server side and @Arun_Rao’s suggestion to Dockerize the server has got me motivated again to create a “roll-your-own” fork of Signal. I adore Signal, and everything the team has done. The one missing element to me is self-hosting, as likely like many of you, I’m of the Nextcloud/GitBucket/etc variety, w…

posts.name: Rama Rao Desai
posts.cooked: Hi what do you mean by self hosting? I can be of help to you in this matter.

posts.name: Aqnouch
posts.cooked: “Self hosting” is deployment of your own Signal-Server, and link the mobiles applications to it, so you will have your own messenger that is 100% independent of the Signal infrastructure, while keeping the same functionalities.

@aqnouch, see the other thread… what @Fmstrat means by self-hosting is not merely installing your own signal-server, and connecting it to commercial services like Amazon S3 and Twilio and so on, but 100% self-hosting i.e. installing your own fork of signal-server which comes in a docker-file and HAS no external dependencies which are not pre-installed. This is a longterm goal very different from the usual installation of signal-server, in other words.

But some aspects of that 100%-self-hosting project would help with installing the usual version of signal-server today, right now. For instance, it is possible to create a docker file which would have pre-configured Linux, PostgreSQL, Redis, JDK, coTURN, and a few other things already installed therein. That would still leave Twilio, S3, CloudFront, GCM, APNS, and a few other external dependencies, but it would cut the number of steps in half … and would further document what was needed in terms of external dependencies.

posts.name: Some One
posts.cooked:
i think a 100% self-hosting app is not a easy to build and also not easy to manage
Seriously talking , if you need to create your own S3 ( for example ) , thee is many opensource
Zenko.io or a personal storage service , but the problem here is the management of other server , ( distrebuted storage , region area , encrypting , etc )

or even if a “newest” version of singal is comming out with a “new” approche to store files , that’s will be more likely a catastrophe to deal with .

even for the twilio SMS validation , you need your own sms getway , with for example “The Jasmin Open source SMS gateway” , configuration etc …

i think if you go for a “self-hosted” solution , you need to admit that you will be never make a update for your server or android solution from the signal project . it will be like a solution build on top of signal the oldest version

the Only solution is the signal developer team make a modular solution ( i know it’s alredy modular , but more and more , or a store server , sms getway , etc …)

posts.name: Jaijo
posts.cooked:
@aqnouch We are planning to host signalapp which should be having 25000 users intially (It should be increase in future). For moving to production mode, Do you recommend high availability and load balancing?
If so can you please provide the documents for doing the same if any. Also what server spec you suggest for doing the same.

posts.name: Trunker
posts.cooked:
Hi
You mean you are launching your own separate app based on Signal’s code?
We too are planning something, is it possible to catch up in private?

Thanks
PS

Well, there are several people that have their own app which is based on one of the official signalapp clients.

  • People hand-compile their own signal4android, for instance, if they need support for android 4.3 like here, Why drop ICS / Jelly Bean support? - #43 by 5_c_d or if they want to experiment with hardlocks here Signal with password encryption PoC or whatever. There is a plaintext-export option in this soft-fork of signal4android which has more color-options as well, How to roll back Signal to its latest pre-design-change version? - #28 by johanw666

  • You can also have your own custom signal4desktop, if you want to have enterKey-sends, or you want to modify the CSS to squeeze 50 avatars into the lefthand pane rather than a dozen-or-so, etc. Shortcut to switch between chats - #6 by 5_c_d

  • Modifying your own signal4ios is tougher, because Apple devices make it hard to sideload without paying iTunes appstore fees, but I believe it can be done with jailbroken iDevices?

All those things are still merely custom clients that still connect to the main signal-server production nodes. So they are not separate apps, they are just slightly modified apps which are used by enthusiasts and people with special constraints/desires/etc. So they are not sold or otherwise redistributed usually, mostly they are just for individuals.

By contrast, what you are reading about here in the signal-server thread (and there are a bunch of similar threads here in the unofficial forums) is people that want to run their own entirely separate server-infrastructure. So they start out by getting their own webhost, usually you need something like 8GB of RAM and a VPS for example, they install their own postgreSQL database, they signup for a bunch of external services that a custom signal-server node depends upon (twilio + s3 + cloudfront + fcm + apns + some others), and after getting everything configured and working, they spend some time securing their internet-facing server-node with firewalls and whatnot.

At this point you have a functional signal-server, but nobody can actually USE it because all the client-apps out there in the wild are connecting to the production signal-server distributed cluster. Therefore, to get your custom signal-server where it is useful/usable, you need to now download and hand-compile (with some minor changes to SIGNAL_URL and related fields that specify where the upstream server is) your own custom client-app.

To avoid a trademark-violation, prior to redistributing this custom app to anybody, you need to remove the Signal™ branding. And once you do redistribute the hand-compiled signal4android / signal4ios / signal4desktop apps to other humans, copyright law demands that you provide them with the GPLv3 source code of your modified app, and also the AGPLv3 source code of your custom signal-server, thereby avoiding copyright infringement.

All of which is a ton of work, and only really gets you into a position where you can now … with your one small server-node and your own handful of endusers … start trying to compete with the millions of endusers on the official signalapp, as well as the hundreds of millions on telegram/viber/line, and the billions of endusers on whatsapp/skype. This is not a market to enter on a whim, in other words. It is heavy-duty competition, most of whom already implement signal-protocol (and the main players all implement Signal™ Protocol via contractual agreements presumably from OWS). That is not to say you cannot make your own chat app, the GPL definitely gives you that freedom. It is just to say, you need to be clear in your mind, what goal you are out to accomplish.

See related thread here, Modifying Signal for use with my company which discussed the business aspects more deeply, as well as GPLV3 licensing and closed project which is similar but more blunt. What, in vague terms, are you planning at the moment? There are plenty of folks here that can try to advise you.

posts.name: Trunker
posts.cooked:
Dear 5_c_d

Appreciate your reply and thank you very much for your explanation on various aspects. I was kinda lost and this gives me a springboard to develop our ideas. Being from the business side of this startup, I’d take a bit longer to understand few things in your post, but I’d be collaborating with my tech guy and also look for some team mates from Signal or other forums to guide us (if not execute) with taking this ahead.

We are a tiny startup from India trying/planning to solve few key areas in the messenger space that has plagued users here. We have pseudo named our startup application as Trunk.

While I wont comment on the tech side of the things, as I am not qualified to respond to you on them, kindly allow me to respond to some points from the business side.

5_c_d:

with your one small server-node and your own handful of endusers … start trying to compete with the millions of endusers on the official signalapp, as well as the hundreds of millions on telegram/viber/line, and the billions of endusers on whatsapp/skype. This is not a market to enter on a whim, in other words. It is heavy-duty competition

Yes I totally agree with your stance. That was and is a shivering thought for any startup (even a biggie). Though our current small research with the individuals and enterprise here in India has led us to discover few key problems that we want to solve for them - and earn a profit on a recurring billing model, looking at the numbers of the competitors is like Finding Nemo in the ocean. We have >1000 (yes, very tiny) people who are interested in a POC, and some businesses have even indicated their interest in paying once the product is ready (though as of now its only a pat on the back, as neither our pricing model is ready nor have we asked them for a payment).

One of the very interested institution is a large prominent Indian bank with whom we had couple long calls; these bank folks from “corporate innovation department” (a misnomer?) knew something like Signal, or RedLine, etc. and were talking to me on a fairly advanced level of business case, though sometimes silly arguments like comparing it with email. . one more a education institution with 5000 pupils, hundreds of teachers (MBA, school, kindergarten, college, etc), yet one more is a telecom operator itself interested to explore Trunk. Yet another small manufacturing company has inquired who are currently using Whatsapp for collaboration with their sales team.

Moreover, I rightly assume that you shared the scary stats not to discourage our startup towards this new venture, but to serve as a cautionary tale, lest we end up as those courageous idiots. But that being said, all the apps you mentioned that are now looking upon us from their towering heights with their millions and billions of users as earth-swallowing monsters, were once a tiny garage startup out to upend and disrupt the giants at that time (Skype, Whatsapp, etc). No one is safe, no one is established forever.

5_c_d:

To avoid a trademark-violation, prior to redistributing this custom app to anybody, you need to remove the Signal™ branding.

Yeah, that is the plan anyway, to rebrand it under our own name, Trunk and then resell, distribute or offer it on a freemium pricing model.

5_c_d:

All those things are still merely custom clients that still connect to the main signal-server production nodes. So they are not separate apps, they are just slightly modified apps which are used by enthusiasts and people with special constraints/desires/etc

These are precisely the things we are evaluating:

  • should we go with slight modification on the client side and use Signal server as the backend (to avoid costs, efforts, etc)

  • is starting out from scratch better afresh, ignoring the Signal ecosystem altogether? (may be we’d recompile the signal server code at our side for learning & development once only to scrap it?)

  • Should we totally open source Trunk app, and build some add-on wrapper service apps on top of the original Signal app, to charge our users with a monthly fee?

All these are questions that are dependent on the kind of functionality, features, ta that Trunk is planning to offer to these users. While we don’t want our app to obviously be restricted to India, our current target is these guys and then spread it from there.

5_c_d:

That is not to say you cannot make your own chat app, the GPL definitely gives you that freedom. It is just to say, you need to be clear in your mind, what goal you are out to accomplish.

This freedom is the thing that led us here to plan to explore the promise of a free land, but now I slowly beginning to see that the free is not so free, be it licensing (that is not my worry now) to the huge effort that will require from our team to keep up with the Joneses (Signal server) . …

5_c_d:
5_c_d:

See related thread here, Modifying Signal for use with my company which discussed the business aspects more deeply, as well as GPLV3 licensing and closed project which is similar but more blun

Yes, have been poring over that since you gave the link and navigating to the links in there. Also have been trying to study the pros and cons of various messenger systems, and the use cases.

What, in vague terms, are you planning at the moment? There are plenty of folks here that can try to advise you.

At our current stage its is currently prohibitively ridiculous for us to be talking – or even thinking – to negotiate with OWS for a licensing arrangement the way Google, FB does to use Signal protocol in the backend. In fact most of our users couldn’t care more about the backend, as they are looking for solutions to their problems, and security is not one of them, as all are already on Whatsapp today reeling under Mark Zuckerburg’s privacy manifesto (Mark offering privacy is like chastity of s*x)

I’m somehow being pushed by an invisible hand to pursue this venture – the hand that has not yet arranged a massive funding, neither bestowed a proper plan, nor a full fledged team. But the deeper I am getting into the messenger space, especially for my user base in India, whom I intricately know with their problems, the more attracted I’m to a strong feeling that I’d be able to crack it for these few thousand paying users (and then roll it to tens of thousands of free/paying customers) if not millions of them.

Rather than project my conjectures too long into the future (and lose my hair) we can, as most startup expert mentors say, focus on the problems and the few sets of user base your solution can help. A few hundred (paying) advocate devotees are far better to have than thousands of mild fans. That being said, my sole reason to come to Signal forum was not just run with the free code, but to elicit guidance from veterans like you on how a tiny ship can navigate the ocean, rather than being safely confined to the shores for which it was not built in the first place.

side note about purpose of SignalUsers, and category-system
Trunk:

Being from the business side of this startup, I’d take a bit longer to understand few things in your post

You are free to ask questions here, although, we ARE in a thread about programming and development (see category up top). I’ve requested a moderator split this off into a more suitable thread, which might happen when they have time.

For now we can continue here, in this thread, since often the Main Reason people want to install their own custom signal-server is they have dreams of being the next Brian Acton and becoming a messenger-industry billionaire. Unfortunately we cannot all be Brians :-)

Trunk:

We are a tiny startup from India …not yet arranged a massive funding, neither bestowed a proper plan, nor a full fledged team … elicit guidance from veterans like you on how a tiny ship can navigate the ocean

Right. You are a tiny ship, with only few sailors and no financial-adventurer backing the voyage, plus the ocean you are wanting to sail is vast and treacherous, filled with hypercorporation sharks that will eat you and your tiny ship. Not for breakfast – that would be a MEAL-sized competitor… you are not even bite-sized, let alone meal-sized.

My point is not to discourage you, but I do want to STRONGLY encourage you to think very seriously about whether you are wanting to risk the vessel and the crew in a solo-around-the-world voyage.

Often the best way to defend against monsters of the deep, is to use a tactical formation designed to keep them at bay. Flotilla - Wikipedia There are several directions that your future startup could travel: you can decide to do it all yourselves. You can decide whether you are a services&consulting&support business rather than a programming&softwareApp business, or some hybrid perhaps. You can form partnerships and join communities that will improve your chances of survival and success, etc.

Because you are a young startup, you have the advantage of being flexible, nimble, able to react quickly. But because you are a young startup, you are small/vulnerable.

Trunk:

focus on the problems and the few sets of user base your solution can help

Exactly.

Trunk:

for my user base in India, whom I intricately know with their problems

This is where you can add value, correct. Signalapp is a solid codebase, but it is not specially tuned to the problems your startup’s future userbase needs solved. Therefore, as long as you concentrate HARD on effectively and efficiently solving those problems for them, you add value, and in return your newfound customers will gladly pay fees.

But it is very difficult to solve problem#1, without accidentally causing problem#2 to rise up and bite your customer on the buttocks. Problem: sales team at a small manufacturer is using whatsapp to coordinate their efforts and [need capability Xyz].

four viable business models, and two biz-plans that are NOT truly viable

  • Solution#A: manufacturer decides to hire TrunkCorp-the-software-as-a-service-firm to build them a completely new thing from scratch, with custom TrunkServer based on AGPLv3 signal-server codebase, custom TrunkClient based on GPLv3 signal4android + signal4ios + signal4winLinOsx codebases, and a single added feature.

    • Problem#2A: the codebase is GPL so the manufacturer can just run it themselves, they need not pay recurring fees.
    • Problem#3A: running signal-server nodes is very hard and expensive, see Server cost analysis , so TrunkCorp has to charge exorbitant fees “just” for that Xyz, and has nowhere near the uptime and speed and reliability of the vast whatsapp distributed server-cluster.
    • Problem#4A: pretty soon the manufacturer fires TrunkCorp.
    • Problem#5A: vessel sinks in the vast ocean, crushed between GPL copyright law and facebook’s billions.

  • Solution#B: same as above, except TrunkCorp negotiates with OWS and Signal Foundation to get a license exception contract, similar to Facebook/Google/Microsoft and their Whatsapp/FbMsgr/Allo/Skype product-lines. Problem#2B: Not feasible for a small startup, although, if you are really sure your team has to have full control of the server-side-codebase, it would not hurt to ask politely, I suppose… try support@signal.org to see if they can direct you to the correct person to talk with about licensing-contracts, if you wish

  • Solution#C: manufacturer decides to hire TrunkCorp-the-software-products-firm, to build them a heavily modified TrunkClient, which will connect with the normal production Signal Server cluster-nodes via the internet, with client-code based on one or more of the GPLv3 signal4android + signal4ios + signal4winLinOsx codebases, and a single added feature.

    • Problem#2C: the codebase is GPL so the manufacturer can just run it themselves, they need not pay recurring fees.

    • Problem#3C: compiling a custom client-app is not very hard nor expensive, so although TrunkCorp fees might be low, the manufacturer’s difficulty with compiling themselves is also low, and there are no reliability-headaches if the manufacturer already has a competent IT department handling their laptops and printers and wifi and such.

    • Problem#4C: pretty soon the manufacturer fires TrunkCorp.

    • Problem#5C: vessel sinks in the vast ocean, crushed between GPL copyright law and picking the wrong business-plan.

    • Problem#6C: even if the manufacturer is inept at IT and keeps paying TrunkCorp, that will be a violation of the signal-server terms (excerpted below). It would be conceivable that Signal Foundation might negotiate a deal with a small startup to permit the customers of their rebranded TrunkApp to use the production servers, but probably not if the client-code was heavily modified (which is the assumption here).

    • Signal >> Terms of Service & Privacy Policy "…you [the enduser of signal-network] consent to downloading and installing updates [from Signal Foundation! not from TrunkCorp copying the GPL’d codebase]…

    • You must not (or assist others to) access, use, modify, distribute, transfer, or exploit our Services in unauthorized manners [i.e. custom re-branded client connecting to signal-server nodes without permission]…

    • create accounts for our Services through unauthorized or automated means [i.e. custom client registering new signal-nums]…

    • collect information about our users in any unauthorized manner [i.e. custom client uploading data about endusers of signal-server to TrunkCorp – which is necessary if you want to keep TrunkApp from crashing]…

    • sell, rent, or charge for our Services [i.e. the idea for TrunkCorp to charge recurring fees to all their customers using TrunkApp+SignalFoundationServers is not going to fly without pre-existing contractual release].

    • …We may modify, suspend, or terminate your access to [i.e. the ability of TrunkClient to connect] or use of our Services [i.e. the signal-nums of Random Manufacturer who is a client of TrunkCorp] anytime for any reason,

    • such as if you violate the letter or spirit [emphasis added] of our Terms or create harm, risk, or possible legal exposure [e.g. liability if manufacturer sues] for Signal."

  • Solution#D. Same as C, except that only a very lightly-modified codebase is used on the client-side, and the re-branding is VERY extensive & complete (such that when TrunkApp connects to production signal-servers there is almost zero possibility that any pathological bug will manifest … but also such that zero reputational harm can fall upon the shoulders of the Signal brand-name should it ever be the case that TrunkApp crashes or fails to work reliably or whatever).

    • Problem#2D: in order for this to jive with the TOS excerpted above, TrunkCorp would need to get authorized-in-writing permission from Signal Foundation and/or OWS to access the production servers with a lightly-modified-from-the-signalapp-github-repo version of TrunkApp. Done carefully, I would judge this as a viable biz-plan in theory but in practice nobody is doing it yet that I am aware, so there is significant risk I’m wrong, or that the idea would be rejected if you proposed it, or whatever.
    • Problem#3D: because you-aka-TrunkCorp would be authorized, and customer-aka-RandomManufacturer would not be authorized, this arrangement would permit you charging a recurring fee, and running a lightly-forked version of signal4android that stayed carefully and promptly in sync with the upstream github-repo (so as not to drift too far out of line with what production servers expected), but also added a few additional features/capabilities on top (which would HAVE to be promptly rebased/reapplied every time Signal Foundation pushed a new APK into the wild which is every 3 weeks or so).

  • Solution#E: manufacturer decides to hire TrunkCorp-the-software-consulting-and-support-services-firm, to build them a communications-solution, either on a project-basis or on a recurring-support-fees basis, or most likely both (large fee the first month and then small maintenance-fees each month thereafter).

    • Problem#2E: in this situation, there is not any re-branding of Signal-Server, or indeed, of Signalapp-client software, the consultants at TrunkCorp just assist the manufacturer-client with installing and configuring and properly securing the normal things.
    • Problem#3E: therefore, although it is conceivable that TrunkCorp can charge recurring fees, in practice most clients under this biz-plan would be project-based rather than permanent. TrunkCorp would get hired, help the manufacturer’s sales team transition away from whatsapp, assist with the selection and configuration of handsets, give training and advice on how to remain secure and avoid opsec failures, and then periodically re-assess whether everything was going smoothly. But at some point, everything WOULD be going smoothly enough, that the manufacturer’s sales team would no longer require TrunkCorp consultants holding their hand, and TrunkCorp’s consulting project would end.
    • Problem#3F: this is a very different biz-plan than with a software-products startup, where the goal is to have a lot of programmers and to monetize their efforts in the form of software-licensing-and-support-fees. With a consulting startup, the goal is to have a lot of technology-savvy people – NOT necessarily programmers although often at least SOME of your consultants better be programmers to help automate stuff – and then monetize the work in the form of training-and-support-fees.
    • In many ways though, this biz-plan is similar to solution D in broad strokes… you might start TrunkCorp on the road to solution E and then evolve into solution D, or vice versa, they are quite compatible. But solution E is a very far cry from solution#A which needs heavy-duty server-sysadmins… you need some people that are tech-savvy when it comes to desktop-sysadmin work and smartphone-sysadmin work with solution E but you really don’t need people savvy with RDBMS-sysadmin work, for instance.
    • Problem#3G: the biggest hurdle to any consulting-type biz-plan is competition, from employees of your clients (manufacturer’s IT department will gradually take over the training-role), but also from competing consulting-firms. Because you are selling expertise and service, rather the licensed software products, the consulting world is very reputation-based, and you will need to be VERY careful to build a strong brand for TrunkCorp as a respected consultancy. This is tougher because you are not rebranding the Signal name, usually, but it can be done.
    • Moreover, because you are not re-branding the software, you can work on becoming known as “the best Signalapp-consulting-firm in western India” or whatever.

  • See the discussion about naval metaphors: Signal Foundation is like the battleship, at the center of the flotilla, and political dissidents are operating nearby submarines under the radar… consulting firms that specialize in corporate data-privacy like TrunkCorp-solution#E are the equivalent of high-speed-destroyers, armed to the teeth with expertise and right out in front, paving the way for the battleship.

  • Solution#F: there is a hybrid sort of biz-plan, where you combine TrunkCorp into multiple kinds of business-models simultaneously. Typically, the way solution F works is that you have a consulting-department, very similar to solution E outlined above, but in addition to your consulting-work you will also provide something along the lines of solution C or even solution A, which is your programming-department. However, instead of running your own custom signal-server nodes as in solution A, or even heavily modifying signal4android as in solution C, your programming-department doesn’t do that stuff.

  • Your consulting-deparment handles stock non-re-branded signalapp installs, and your manufacturer-client does not run modified a codebase, they just connect to the production Signal Foundation servers, like in solution E. But in addition to your consulting-arm helping the manufacturer install signalapp for secure comms, you also sell a line of complementary software-products. Signalapp does not have a plugin system, but it does integrate with several other apps: therefore, solution F is to have the programming-arm of TrunkCorp improve things that are not compiled into signalapp (and thus can be relicensed without violating the GPLv3 license-terms).

    • So for example, signalapp depends on the stock vKeyboard, and this is insecure. You might have your consulting-arm of TrunkCorp research and recommend an alternative vKeyb app… or you might have your programming-arm create a more private vKeyb app, which would then improve signalapp every time the vKeyb was opened – instead of being the gBoard it would the the trunkKeyb app.
    • Signalapp integrates with the stock addressbook-app, much like whatsapp… but with the downside that the stock addressbook app tends to suck :-) Therefore, consulting-arm can research alternative addressbook projects that manufacturer could install instead, and/or programming-arm can create a better addressbook-app.
    • Third example: signalapp does not come with a VPN, but like all other apps on the smartphone, it uses a VPN, so you can either recommend the best VPN option via consulting-arm, or write a better TrunkVpnApp that you upsell.
    • Fourth example: backups, signalapp does them, but only partially, and not very user-friendly.
    • Fifth example: local encryption, signalapp just relies upon the OS for most of that, the consultancy-arm can research Samsung SecureFolder as well as LineageOS secondary-android-system-profiles, the programming-arm can implement a veracrypt port to the android platform.
    • Sixth example: signalapp can transmit photos of contracts, but only over-compressed or not-compressed-enough, so there is a need for TrunkTranscoderApp.
    • Seventh example: signalapp can transmit spreadsheets but neither view them nor edit them, by default the get loaded into googleSheets and sent to the cloud! Sheesh. This means the TrunkSpreadsheetApp would be a boon to any sales-team at TrunkCorp clients.

  • There are dozens of other ways that TrunkCorp can write software, license it for recurrent billing, and install it at the same time as … but not actually compiled into … signalapp as the comms-solution. If solution E is the fast-moving destroyer out in front of the signalapp battleship, solution F is the heavy-cruiser that beefs up the defenses where the battleship is relatively weak.

  • Solution G: Well, most of the time, at least, solution F is like a cruiser when you have a lot of consultants and just a few programmers. But if you have a large number of consultants and an even LARGER number of programmers working away on dozens of TrunkCorp apps (not just one or two), which deploy side-by-side with signalapp, now you are more like a aircraft-carrier than a heavy-cruiser, you have gone onto offense and no longer are mainly defensive in nature.

  • Solution H1: those above are the main options, but there are various other business-plan models, which can sometimes make sense. There are at least a couple people who participate here in the forums, that sell consulting-services helping folks setup their own custom signal-server-nodes, and charging a project-fee on a short term basis (usually just a few hours of sysadmin effort).

  • Solution H2: you could imagine starting a training-business, where instead of you and your consultants going to the client-site to help them get signalapp up and running, THEY sent employees to your seminars, where you spoke about corporate-data-protection strategy.

  • Solution H3. and so on, there are hundreds of variations on the flotilla-theme, which are viable business-models.

But most people, who are often new to the concept of signal-server, immediately tend to think “hey if I want to have a startup related to the messenging-industry then I better compile my own custom signal-server right now”. This is the wrong idea, 999 times out of 1000, though sometimes it is the only way (in which case see solution#B… just be sure that is the only solution).

Trunk:

assume that you shared the scary stats not to discourage our startup towards this new venture, but to serve as a cautionary tale

Partly as a cautionary tale, but primarily to encourage you to think hard about your business-plan. Incorrect choice of biz-plan, in the early phase of your startup effort, means that you have to “change horses mid-stream” as the old saying goes. Pick the right horse first, and only begin crossing the raging river … or sailing off into the shark-infested ocean or whatever the case might be … BEFOREHAND, so you don’t have to backtrack that decision later on.

Trunk:

We have >1000 (yes, very tiny) people who are interested in a POC, and some businesses have even indicated their interest in paying once the product is ready …a large prominent Indian bank … education institution with 5000 pupils, hundreds of teachers (MBA, school, kindergarten … a telecom operator … small manufacturing company has inquired who are currently using Whatsapp

That is not tiny, in my book. Sounds like you have a lot of potential, you are not the average startup with a bright idea only, zero clients on tap. Look at the bizplan selections I outline above, please. You can viably run TrunkCorp as a solution#G aircraft-carrier, or as a solution#F heavy-cruiser, or as a solution#E fast-moving-destroyer, and use Signal Foundation as your flotilla battleship. You don’t have to make any deals or negotiate any contracts or pay any fees, you just have to “sail in the same general direction” and you benefit from the battleship’s power without the need to install and maintain and compile your own battleship-equipment :-)

Solution#D is also conceivably viable, and maybe even solution#B if you have enough money and negotiating-power, but those are not legal without directly coordinating some sort of contractual agreement with OWS and/or Signal Foundation. My recommendation would be, if you are planning something that requires D-type things at some point, start out with E and then shift over when and if negotiations pan out. Signal Foundation doesn’t have a lot of lawyers and salesfolks out trying to sell their product-line, they are a non-profit venture that concentrates on customer service, so it will take awhile before you even get to TALK to anybody, most likely. Maybe forever ;-)

You should avoid A and C though, which are just rocky shoals that will screw up your startup’s voyage before you have even gotten properly underway.

posts.name: Fredrick Paul Eisele
posts.cooked: The original gist is dead, long live the new gist

posts.name: Joe
posts.cooked: Anyone considering doing this needs to go into it with eyes wide open. Installing signal server is a multicloud deployment using services on AWS, Azure and GCP along with a bunch of API services such as Twilio and Swipe. At least two components must run on platforms that support Intel SGX, which at this point is Azure and IBM Cloud. You will need to modify the code for iOS, Android, Desktop, and libsignal (there are hardcoded host urls for CDSI and SVR2) which is in Rust. There is no documentation but a few bread crumbs. You have to spend a ton of time reading the code to figure out what you need and how to configure it. I spent all of 2024 doing this and it is VERY difficult to do.

posts.name: Felix A. Croes
posts.cooked:
It is definitely difficult, and not getting easier as Signal Server evolves.

I went a different way – I wrote a replacement for Signal Server, from scratch. Libsignal in Rust was replaced by this in C, the rest was written in LPC. It took me 8 months altogether to get to a stage where clients can send messages to eachother, most of it spent figuring out what Signal Server was doing.

GitHub - LPC-language/signal-server: A reimplementation of https://github.com/signalapp/Signal-Server in LPC.

posts.name: Joe
posts.cooked: @Dworkin That’s awesome news! I toyed with rewriting it in Rust, but really don’t have the time. I did help a team to get the current implementation fully up and running. I also modified the registration service to use LDAP and Active Directory. Learned a lot in the process.
